channel.title: Questions about Bot Development
channel.description: I understand how to aproach forcing actions in any version of the client, I also know how detectible this is. I was wondering if using the Java's robot package within the client for auto typing, clicking, and set x/y clicking (but not for actual macroing - since java is terrible with color recognition) would be a good idea (it will use smooth mouse movement). However, how would I go about aproaching a substitute for forcing actions?

item.title: Questions about Bot Development
item.dc:creator: @newbiehacker newbiehacker
item.description:
@newbiehacker wrote:

Erm no you don’t…

A much easier solution would be to simply override the EventQueue, that way you can pretty much control what goes in and out

Read full topic

item.title: Questions about Bot Development
item.dc:creator: @ownagesbot ownagesbot
item.description:
@ownagesbot wrote:

Look, their action listener logs every event used on the canvas, thus you have to hijack it someway and filter out what you dont want or whatever. I did this by removing their action listener from the canvas instance (which I got through bcel), and then added mine, I then sent it through their listener, which I also got from using bcel.

Read full topic

item.title: Questions about Bot Development
item.dc:creator: @Ollie Ollie
item.description:
@Ollie wrote:

ownagesbot:

… doing that means you still have to hijack the listener idiot.

what about editing the eventque to send events?

Read full topic

… doing that means you still have to hijack the listener idiot.

item.description:
@ilyaostr9 wrote:

@mopar: OR you can send fake AWTEvents(that’s probably what my bot’ gonna do), unless that’s what Cherokee does.

item.title: Questions about Bot Development
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

You can use the input methods from Cherokee for undetectability while still being able to use your computer.

Read full topic

item.title: Questions about Bot Development
item.dc:creator: @Iamadam Iamadam
item.description:
@Iamadam wrote:

[quote=“zraffz, post:3, topic:59677”][quote author=popcorn89 link=topic=85649.msg914083#msg914083 date=1171794405]
Basically all you need to do is use information from the client to determine the mouse coordinates of whatever it is you’re looking for. As for moving the mouse, it doesn’t really matter. I prefer to directly call the MouseListener methods, but it’s up to you.
[/quote]
so would calling for the robot mouse movements within where the client calls for mouse listening mean the mouse cursor wont actually move? (I am asking, because I am thinking that it still will control the mouse, and if it does I dont really want to do it.)[/quote]
It will move the mouse. That’s why you should hijack the listeners instead
Oh, and java is great at color-clicking (Have a look at ibot)

Read full topic

item.title: Questions about Bot Development
item.dc:creator: @zraffz zraffz
item.description:
@zraffz wrote:

popcorn89:

Basically all you need to do is use information from the client to determine the mouse coordinates of whatever it is you’re looking for. As for moving the mouse, it doesn’t really matter. I prefer to directly call the MouseListener methods, but it’s up to you.

so would calling for the robot mouse movements within where the client calls for mouse listening mean the mouse cursor wont actually move? (I am asking, because I am thinking that it still will control the mouse, and if it does I dont really want to do it.)

Read full topic

item.title: Questions about Bot Development
item.dc:creator: @popcorn89 popcorn89
item.description:
@popcorn89 wrote:

Basically all you need to do is use information from the client to determine the mouse coordinates of whatever it is you’re looking for. As for moving the mouse, it doesn’t really matter. I prefer to directly call the MouseListener methods, but it’s up to you.

Read full topic
